The machine has 2GB memory and I started heritrix with -Xmx1200m. I 
have another program (tomcat) which I started with -Xmx800m. But 
tomcat is mostly idle.

Let me try the hold-queues parameter and see how it works.

Thanks,

--- In archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com, "Gordon Mohr (Internet 
Archive)" <gojomo@a...> wrote:
> Memory use (and traffic to disk) is more a function of the
> number of hosts/queues that have been discovered or active,
> than of the total number of URLs discovered or crawled. So
> any 'broader' crawls will strain resources more than
> 'narrower' ones with a smaller or fixed number of hosts
> of interest.
> 
> Your machine may be swapping heavily. Things to check:
> 
>   - Does 'top' show swap in use?
>   - How does your configured max heap and current heap size
>     compare with RAM? (Max heap should be 25% or more smaller
>   - Do the 'si' and 'so' columns in 'vmstat 2'
>     (sample every 2 seconds) show activity?
> 
> Separately from OS virtual memory, the new BDB/soft-reference
> mechanism for 'paging' per-host/per-queue data out when not in
> immediate use could theoretically reach some excessive IO states
> in low-memory conditions. This would be more likely if you weren't
> using the 'hold-queues' setting and were instead round-robinning
> among all queues in a big crawl.
> 
> - Gordon @ IA
> 
> joehung302 wrote:
> > I started a crawl about a week ago (using 1.4 broad scope and 
the 
> > default BdbFrontier). So far I've collected >7 million docs but 
IO is 
> > consistently at >50% using top. Sometimes even higher at 90+%.
> > 
> > Here is what's interesting...even if I pause the crawl, IO is 
still 
> > busy. The number never dropped.
> > 
> > I'm running on a dual Xeon with a direct attached SCSI array, 
using 
> > Sun's JDK 1.4.2. -Xmx1200.
> > 
> > I've done a 7 million docs crawl using 1.0.4 before on the same 
> > hardware (using domainscope though). From what I remember the 
disk IO 
> > was at around 5%. 
> > 
> > Is it becuase of BdbFrontier? Any hints?
> > 
> > Thanks,
> > 
> > -joe
